template_01.name: statistics
template_01.main_feature: Present charts and explanations in a personalised canvas. Include bar charts, line charts, doughnut charts and more!

discover_music_data_on_the_web.title: Discover music data on the Web
discover_music_data_on_the_web.description: musoW is a catalogue of musical resources available on the web realized with the idea to support teachers in music education, creative industries, historians, and musicologists in finding what they need.

dynamic_elements.text: The catalogue includes descriptions of several music-related web resources, with a focus on those that serve or allow users to manipulate music data in any form.

dynamic_elements.count_query: SELECT (COUNT(*) AS ?count) WHERE {?s ?p <https://w3id.org/musow/vocab/repository>.}
SELECT (COUNT(*) AS ?count) WHERE {?s ?p <https://w3id.org/musow/vocab/catalogue>.}
SELECT (COUNT(*) AS ?count) WHERE {?s ?p <https://w3id.org/musow/vocab/dataset>.}
SELECT (COUNT(*) AS ?count) WHERE {?s ?p <https://w3id.org/musow/vocab/digital-library>.}

dynamic_elements.chart_query:
PREFIX musow: <https://w3id.org/musow/vocab/> 
SELECT ?label (COUNT(?content) AS ?count) 
WHERE { {?content ?p musow:repository . musow:repository rdfs:label ?label .} UNION {?content ?p musow:catalogue . musow:catalogue rdfs:label ?label .} UNION {?content ?p musow:dataset . musow:dataset rdfs:label ?label .} UNION {?content ?p musow:digital-library . musow:digital-library rdfs:label ?label .} UNION {?content ?p musow:software . musow:software rdfs:label ?label .} } GROUP BY ?label

dynamic_elements.text: While collecting information about resources is important, we also focused on understanding the potential audience of the resources. We discovered that most of surveyed resources are targeted to scholars.

dynamic_elements.chart_query: SELECT ?label WHERE { ?entry ?p <https://w3id.org/musow/vocab/repository> . ?entry <https://schema.org/audience> ?audience . ?audience rdfs:label ?label . }

relations_between_museums.title: Relations between museums
relations_between_museums.subtitle: Explore relations between artists in museums
relations_between_museums.description: Search for museums, choose from the list of results, click on the buttons that appear next to the result and keep exploring relations. New tables will appear, including more actions and relations to explore.

dynamic_elements.tablevalueaction_title: show other museums in this country

relations_between_music_bands_an_explora.title: Relations between music bands - An exploration
relations_between_music_bands_an_explora.subtitle: Explore relations, connections and resources between music bands with wikidata
relations_between_music_bands_an_explora.description: Search for music bands, choose from the list of results, click on the buttons that appear next to the result and keep exploring relations. New tables will appear, including more actions and relations to explore.

mapping_us_recording_studios.title: Mapping US Recording Studios
mapping_us_recording_studios.subtitle: Two maps show recording studios in the world
mapping_us_recording_studios.description: Important recording studios are more than just bricks, mortar, and audio equipment to musicians. Let's map all the recording studios locations available on wikidata and lets take a closer look at recording studios in the US.

dynamic_elements.map_points_query:
SELECT DISTINCT ?point ?pointLabel ?villeIdLabel ?lat ?long
WHERE
{
  ?point wdt:P31 wd:Q746369. #recording studio
  ?point wdt:P131 ?villeId.
  ?point p:P625 ?statement.
  ?statement psv:P625 ?node.
  ?node wikibase:geoLatitude ?lat.
  ?node wikibase:geoLongitude ?long.
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "en". }
}

dynamic_elements.action_query:
SELECT DISTINCT ?pic ?animal ?animalLabel (SAMPLE(?colorlabel) as ?Colour)
WHERE {
  ?animal wdt:P279* wd:Q729 .
  ?animal wdt:P495 <<item>> .
  ?animal wdt:P18 ?pic .
  ?animal wdt:P462 ?color .
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "en".}
  SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "en".
          ?color rdfs:label ?colorlabel.
      }
  FILTER regex(str(?pic), "jpg").
}
GROUP BY ?pic ?animal ?animalLabel
LIMIT 10

through_the_prism_of_diversity.title: Through the Prism of Diversity
through_the_prism_of_diversity.subtitle: Discover the Intriguing Links: Human Origins, Eye Colours, and Feline Companions Unveiled!
through_the_prism_of_diversity.description: Come join us on an exciting journey that combines data visualizations and storytelling, revealing the captivating connections between human origins, eye colours, and the special bonds we form with our beloved feline pals. This concise data story takes you deep into the realms of human history, genetic diversity, and the irresistible charm of our mysterious furry companions. Get ready to be amazed!

dynamic_elements.text: With a staggering count of more that 10 millions individuals, the vast and diverse realm of humanity comes to life within the expansive realm of Wikidata. This digital repository of knowledge encapsulates a wealth of information about people from all walks of life, spanning cultures, eras, and continents.

dynamic_elements.map_title: Continents Revealed: Mapping the Birthplaces of some Individuals

dynamic_elements.chart_title: Eye Candy: the Kaleidoscope of Common Eye Colours
dynamic_elements.chart_query:
SELECT ?label (COUNT(?human) AS ?count)
WHERE
{
  ?human wdt:P31 wd:Q5.
  ?human wdt:P1340 ?eyeColor.
  ?eyeColor rdfs:label ?label .
  FILTER(lang(?label) = "en")

}
GROUP BY ?label
ORDER BY DESC(?count)
LIMIT 10

dynamic_elements.text: From rich chocolate browns to sparkling emeralds, and from oceanic blues to mysterious hazels, behold the mesmerising kaleidoscope of eye colours that captivate our hearts. Each slice of the chart gives you a sneak peek into the abundance of people rocking those fabulous eye hues, letting you see the relative popularity at a glance.
Paws and Companions: Exploring the Pet Owners among Wikidata's Human Tapestry
Let's take a closer look at these incredible duos.

dynamic_elements.table_title: Purrfect Pals: Cat Owners and Their Furry Friends

dynamic_elements.text: Each entry unveils a unique story of love, devotion, and the extraordinary bonds forged between humans and their beloved pets.

Building upon the cool cats listed in the table, we've got a whole lot more to uncover about their intriguing characteristics. Want to know about similar breeds, hair colours, or even the reasons behind their goodbyes? Just pick a cat's name from the table, and get ready to be blown away by the awesome info that's waiting for you. Let the adventure begin!

dutch_broadcast_concert_collection.title: Dutch Broadcast Concert Collection
dutch_broadcast_concert_collection.subtitle: Exploring live concerts on Dutch television and radio
dutch_broadcast_concert_collection.description: The Dutch Broadcast Concert Collection (Dutch name MOZ - Muziekopnamen Zendgemachtigden) contains recordings of concerts broadcast live by Dutch public service broadcasters, and metadata describing the recordings, including related persons.

dynamic_elements.count_query:
PREFIX schema: <http://schema.org/>
PREFIX sdo: <https://schema.org/>
PREFIX rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#>
PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#>


SELECT DISTINCT (COUNT(?program) AS ?count) 
WHERE { 

  	?series <https://schema.org/name> "Muziekopnamen Zendgemachtigden (MOZ)"^^xsd:string .  
	?season sdo:partOfSeries ?series . 
  ?program sdo:partOfSeason ?season .  
}

PREFIX schema: <http://schema.org/>
PREFIX skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#>
PREFIX sdo: <https://schema.org/>
PREFIX rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#>
PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#>

SELECT (COUNT(distinct ?entityName) as ?count)
WHERE {
?series <https://schema.org/name> "Muziekopnamen Zendgemachtigden (MOZ)"^^xsd:string .  
	?season sdo:partOfSeries ?series . 
  ?program_uri sdo:partOfSeason ?season . 
  {
    ?program_uri a sdo:CreativeWork ;
      (sdo:about|sdo:mentions|sdo:creator|sdo:contributor|sdo:actor|sdo:crew|sdo:performer)/
      (sdo:about|sdo:mentions|sdo:creator|sdo:contributor|sdo:actor|sdo:crew|sdo:performer) ?entity  .
    ?entity skos:prefLabel ?entityName
  }
  UNION
  {
    ?program_uri sdo:isPartOfSeason ?season .

    ?season  (sdo:about|sdo:mentions|sdo:creator|sdo:contributor|sdo:actor|sdo:crew|sdo:performer)/
    (sdo:about|sdo:mentions|sdo:creator|sdo:contributor|sdo:actor|sdo:crew|sdo:performer) ?entity  .

    ?entity skos:prefLabel ?entityName
  }
  UNION
  {
    ?program_uri sdo:isPartOfSeason/sdo:isPartOfSeries ?series .

    ?series  (sdo:about|sdo:mentions|sdo:creator|sdo:contributor|sdo:actor|sdo:crew|sdo:performer)/
    (sdo:about|sdo:mentions|sdo:creator|sdo:contributor|sdo:actor|sdo:crew|sdo:performer) ?entity  .

    ?entity skos:prefLabel ?entityName
  }
  UNION
  {
    ?scene sdo:hasPart ?program_uri.

    ?scene  (sdo:about|sdo:mentions|sdo:creator|sdo:contributor|sdo:actor|sdo:crew|sdo:performer)/
    (sdo:about|sdo:mentions|sdo:creator|sdo:contributor|sdo:actor|sdo:crew|sdo:performer) ?entity  .

    ?entity skos:prefLabel ?entityName 
  }
}

dynamic_elements.chart_query:
PREFIX schema: <http://schema.org/>
PREFIX sdo: <https://schema.org/>
PREFIX rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#>
PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#>
PREFIX xsd: <http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#>


SELECT ?label
WHERE {
  	?series <https://schema.org/name> "Muziekopnamen Zendgemachtigden (MOZ)"^^xsd:string .  
	?season sdo:partOfSeries ?series . 
  ?program sdo:partOfSeason ?season .  
  ?program <https://schema.org/datePublished> ?date .
  BIND(substr(?date, 1, 4) as ?label)}

dynamic_elements.text: The concerts span a time range from 1934 through to the present day. Note that the data point in 1900 comes from a concert that cannot be more precisely dated than to the twentieth century.

dynamic_elements.chart_title: Roles of persons in the concert collection
dynamic_elements.chart_query:
PREFIX schema: <http://schema.org/>
PREFIX skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#>
PREFIX sdo: <https://schema.org/>
PREFIX rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#>
PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#>

# Toon alleen items die ook op GPP te bekijken/beluisteren zijn.
SELECT ?count ?label
WHERE{
  {
SELECT (COUNT(distinct ?entityName) as ?count) ?role
WHERE {
?series <https://schema.org/name> "Muziekopnamen Zendgemachtigden (MOZ)"^^xsd:string .  
	?season sdo:partOfSeries ?series . 
  ?program_uri sdo:partOfSeason ?season . 
    ?program_uri a sdo:CreativeWork .
    ?program_uri ?role ?roleEntity . ?roleEntity ?role ?entity  .
    ?entity skos:prefLabel ?entityName
    } group by ?role  LIMIT 3}
?role rdfs:label ?label}order by desc(?count)

dynamic_elements.text: Persons in the collection either performed music, or created it, or were simply mentioned in the concert metadata. The donut chart above shows that most of the persons included in the collection have the role of performer (linked to concerts with the property byArtist).

This graph shows the top five most frequently occurring creators in the concert collection. International classical composers such as Beethoven and Mozart are mixed with modern musicians such as Jean-Pierre Gabriël, who conducts multiple orchestras in the Netherlands, Ron Ford, a Dutch-American composer, and Myrthe van Dijk, who composed songs for the iconic 'Kinderen voor Kinderen' youth choir.

Plotting the top ten performers reveals that the collection has an emphasis on music performed by orchestras, choirs and ensembles. Dolf van der Linden, a Dutch conductor, and Marinus Voorberg, a Dutch conductor and pianist, also feature in the top ten.
All concerts are under copyright. They were produced by a variety of production companies

The production companies reflect the diversity of the collection. From Omroep MAX, a public service broadcaster that serves older viewers, to Mojo Concerts, an important concert promotor in the Netherlands.

overview_of_bells_in_liguria.title: Overview of bells in Liguria
overview_of_bells_in_liguria.curator: Fabrizio Magnani, Elena Musumeci, Chiara Veninata
overview_of_bells_in_liguria.description: In Liguria, the art of bell-making is very widespread, thanks also to the historical presence of numerous foundries, now closed. Depending on the location, the number of bells for each bell tower differs.

dynamic_elements.text:
In the Genoese and Levant areas from the 1960s onwards we witness an increase in the number of bells contained in every bell tower and the birth of the first numerous sets, reaching as many as 12 bells.

In the Ponente, on the other hand, it still remains the main one, given the average of 3 sets, a maximum of 5 bells for a tower. 

The geographical distribution of the bells on the territory is a very interesting fact because it can help to highlight many aspects. In fact, we can understand what the density of the bells is by area, but also make an initial assessment of the possible impact on the soundscape.

dynamic_elements.count_query:
PREFIX a-cd: <https://w3id.org/arco/ontology/context-description/>
PREFIX clv: <https://w3id.org/italia/onto/CLV/>
PREFIX l0: <https://w3id.org/italia/onto/l0/>
prefix dc: <http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/>
prefix a-loc: <https://w3id.org/arco/ontology/location/>

SELECT (COUNT(DISTINCT ?church) AS ?count)
WHERE {
?setOfBells a-cd:isLocatedIn ?church ;
dc:subject ?o FILTER(str(?o)='concerto di campane' || str(?o)='campana') .
?setOfBells a-loc:hasCulturalPropertyAddress ?cpa .
?cpa clv:hasProvince ?province .
?province l0:name ?prov FILTER(str(?prov)='GE') .
}

dynamic_elements.map_points_query:
PREFIX clv: <https://w3id.org/italia/onto/CLV/>
PREFIX cis: <http://dati.beniculturali.it/cis/>
SELECT DISTINCT ?point ?lat ?long SAMPLE(?addres as ?address) ?region

WHERE {
?setOfBells a-cd:isLocatedIn ?point; dc:subject ?o FILTER(str(?o)='concerto di campane' || str(?o)='campana') .
?setOfBells a-loc:hasCulturalPropertyAddress ?cpa .
?cpa clv:hasRegion ?reg .
?reg l0:name ?region FILTER(str(?region)='Liguria') .
?point a-loc:hasCulturalPropertyAddress ?a ; clv:hasGeometry ?g.
?a rdfs:label ?addres .
?g a-loc:hasCoordinates ?coord .
?coord a-loc:lat ?lat ; a-loc:long ?long.
}

map_filters.map_filter_query:
PREFIX a-cd: <https://w3id.org/arco/ontology/context-description/>
PREFIX clv: <https://w3id.org/italia/onto/CLV/>
PREFIX l0: <https://w3id.org/italia/onto/l0/>
prefix a-loc: <https://w3id.org/arco/ontology/location/>
SELECT DISTINCT ?point ?filter (SAMPLE(?label) as ?filterLabel)
WHERE {
?point a-loc:hasCulturalPropertyAddress ?cpa .
?cpa clv:hasProvince ?filter;
clv:hasRegion ?region .
?region l0:name ?reg FILTER(str(?reg)='Liguria') .
?filter rdfs:label ?label .
}

dynamic_elements.chart_query:
PREFIX a-cd: <https://w3id.org/arco/ontology/context-description/>
PREFIX clv: <https://w3id.org/italia/onto/CLV/>
PREFIX l0: <https://w3id.org/italia/onto/l0/>
prefix a-loc: <https://w3id.org/arco/ontology/location/>

SELECT ?label 
WHERE {
?setOfBells a-cd:isLocatedIn ?church ;
dc:subject ?o FILTER(str(?o)='concerto di campane' || str(?o)='campana') .
?setOfBells a-loc:hasCulturalPropertyAddress ?cpa .
?cpa clv:hasProvince ?l ;
clv:hasRegion ?region .
?region l0:name ?reg FILTER(str(?reg)='Liguria') .
?l rdfs:label ?label .
}

dynamic_elements.text: Bells made with the intention of producing a functional sound are usually made by casting a bronze alloy. Over the course of history there has been a lot of experimentation to achieve the best results; However, the best recognized composition for melting bells is a ratio of around 80% copper and 20% tin. Other materials occasionally used for casting bells are brass or iron. Steel was tried in the mid 19th century in England for its lower cost than bronze, but it was found to be not durable and production ceased in 1870. Glass was also made. but although the bells of this type produced a pleasant sound, this substance being very fragile was unable to withstand continued use.

dynamic_elements.chart_query:
PREFIX a-cd: <https://w3id.org/arco/ontology/context-description/>
PREFIX clv: <https://w3id.org/italia/onto/CLV/>
PREFIX l0: <https://w3id.org/italia/onto/l0/>
prefix a-loc: <https://w3id.org/arco/ontology/location/>
prefix ti: <https://w3id.org/italia/onto/TI/>

SELECT ?label
WHERE {
?bell a arco:MusicHeritage ;
a-cd:hasDating ?dating ;
dc:subject ?o FILTER(str(?o)='campana') .
?dating a-cd:hasDatingEvent ?datingEv .
?datingEv rdfs:label ?datingEvType FILTER(str(?datingEvType)='realizzazione') .
?datingEv a-cd:specificTime ?when .
?when arco:startTime ?label .
}

dynamic_elements.text: The bell casting date is very relevant for the reconstruction of the history that characterizes this artifact in the territory, and connects to other relevant information such as the presence of foundries in the area, the shape of the bells and the sound produced. It is also very relevant for the protection of cultural heritage

dynamic_elements.table_title: or watch some videos and images

music_in_bologna_textual_corpus_overview.title: Music in Bologna - Textual corpus overview
music_in_bologna_textual_corpus_overview.subtitle: Exploring Bologna's role in music history through Knowledge Extraction
music_in_bologna_textual_corpus_overview.curator: Valentina Carriero, Arianna Graciotti, Eleonora Marzi, Valentina Presutti
music_in_bologna_textual_corpus_overview.description: MusicBO corpus contains 135 texts in 4 languages (Italian, English, French, and Spanish) published between 1800 and today and referring to a period between 1600 to the present. We processed the corpus with Natural Language Processing and Understanding (NLP/NLU) technologies to retrieve, integrate and disseminate knowledge about Bologna's role in the European musical landscape.

dynamic_elements.count_query:
SELECT (COUNT(DISTINCT ?s) AS ?count) 
WHERE {?s rdf:type <http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/ont/amr/Person>}

SELECT (COUNT(DISTINCT ?s) AS ?count) 
WHERE {?s rdf:type <http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/ont/amr/Organization>}

SELECT (COUNT(DISTINCT ?s) AS ?count) 
WHERE {?s rdf:type <http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/ont/amr/Country>}

SELECT (COUNT(DISTINCT ?s) AS ?count) 
WHERE {?s rdf:type <http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/ont/amr/City>}
SELECT (COUNT(DISTINCT ?s) AS ?count) WHERE {?s rdf:type <http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/ont/amr/Work-of-art>}

SELECT (COUNT(DISTINCT ?s) AS ?count) 
WHERE {?s rdf:type <http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/ont/amr/Publication>}

dynamic_elements.chart_query:
SELECT ?label (count(distinct ?s) as ?count)  
WHERE {?s rdf:type ?class; <http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/ont/amr/name> ?name   
FILTER regex(str(?class), "(?:^http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/ont/amr/)")      BIND (REPLACE(STR(?class), "^.+?([^/#]+)$", "$1") as ?label)} 
GROUP BY ?label   
ORDER BY DESC (?count) 
LIMIT 10

dynamic_elements.text: We analysed MusicBO corpus through the lens of Named Entities Recognition (NER), a standard Natural Language Processing task. We discovered that the entanglement of Bologna and music history is a composite network of people, places, and organizations. Publications, works of art and books are frequently mentioned in the corpus, revealing that Bologna was an important centre for artistic production.

dynamic_elements.chart_query:
PREFIX rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#>  
PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#>  
SELECT distinct ?label (count(distinct ?s) as ?count)  
WHERE {?s rdf:type <http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/ont/amr/Person> . ?frameInstance ?p ?s ; rdf:type ?frame . ?frame rdfs:label ?label }  
GROUP BY ?label  
ORDER BY DESC(?count) 
LIMIT 10

dynamic_elements.text: According to the insights extracted from the MusicBO corpus through NLP and NLU techniques, people linked to Bologna and related to music were mainly involved in events and situations that implied the creation and production of art.

dynamic_elements.chart_query:
PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#>  
PREFIX dul: <http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/ont/dul/DUL.owl#>    
SELECT ?label (count(distinct ?frameInstance) as ?count)  
WHERE {?s rdf:type <http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/ont/amr/Person> . ?frameInstance ?p ?s ; rdf:type ?frame . ?frame rdfs:label ?frameLabel . ?frame rdfs:subClassOf dul:Event .   
?s <http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/ont/amr/name> ?label  
FILTER (!regex(str(?s), "san_petronio",'i'))}  
   
GROUP BY ?label   
ORDER BY DESC (?count)
LIMIT 10

dynamic_elements.text: Among the many people in the MusicBO corpus, Rossini is the most frequently mentioned as involved in events and situations.

dynamic_elements.chart_title: Top 10 roles played by people in different types of situations
dynamic_elements.chart_query:
PREFIX rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#> 
PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#>
SELECT distinct ?label (count(distinct ?s) as ?count) 
WHERE {?s rdf:type <http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/ont/amr/Person> . ?frameInstance ?p ?s ; rdf:type ?frame . 
#?frame rdfs:label ?label  
BIND (REPLACE(STR(?p), "^.*/([^/]*)$", "$1") as ?label)  
FILTER (!regex(str(?p), "entity_"))  
FILTER (!regex(str(?p), "#"))  
FILTER (!regex(str(?p), "subset")) }  
GROUP BY ?label  
ORDER BY DESC(?count) 
LIMIT 10

dynamic_elements.text: What roles did people linked to music and the city of Bologna played? Characters relevant to the music scene that crossed Bologna over the centuries were mostly authors and artists, but also office holders, writers, agents, and editors. Such insights suggest that Bologna was both a point of reference for artistic production and for music-related activities, as criticism and business. Last but not least, Bologna attracted music students.

dynamic_elements.map_title: Bologna as a lively cultural centre in Europe
dynamic_elements.map_points_query:
PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#>
PREFIX dul: <http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/ont/dul/DUL.owl#>
PREFIX owl: <http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#>
PREFIX rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#>
PREFIX dbpedia: <http://dbpedia.org/resource/>
PREFIX sc: <http://purl.org/science/owl/sciencecommons/>
PREFIX schema: <http://schema.org/>
PREFIX wdt: <http://www.wikidata.org/prop/direct/>
PREFIX wikibase: <http://wikiba.se/ontology#>
PREFIX p: <http://www.wikidata.org/prop/>
PREFIX wd: <http://www.wikidata.org/entity/>
PREFIX ps: <http://www.wikidata.org/prop/statement/>
PREFIX psv: <http://www.wikidata.org/prop/statement/value/>
PREFIX wdr: <http://www.w3.org/2007/05/powder#>
PREFIX amr: <http://www.ontologydesignpatterns.org/ont/amr/> 
SELECT DISTINCT ?point ?label ?frameInstance ?lat ?long
WHERE { ?cityUri rdf:type amr:City ;  owl:sameAs ?point ;  amr:name ?label .  
	FILTER (regex(str(?point), "http://www.wikidata.org/entity/", "i"))  
	?frameInstance ?p ?cityUri ; rdf:type ?frame .  
SERVICE <https://query.wikidata.org/bigdata/namespace/wdq/sparql> { 
	?point wdt:P31/wdt:P279* wd:Q515 .  
	?point p:P625 ?coords_stmt .  
	?coords_stmt ps:P625 ?coords; 
	psv:P625 [  wikibase:geoLatitude ?lat;  wikibase:geoLongitude ?long ] . }
}

frequently_occurring_patterns.title: Frequently Occurring Patterns
frequently_occurring_patterns.subtitle: FoNN - FOlk N-gram aNalysis
frequently_occurring_patterns.description: FoNN is a software component implementing similarity measures for melodies based on n-gram models. FONN defines several variations of patterns as n-grams. In this story, we define a pattern as a 6-gram of pitch classes in the melody. Have a look at the list of the top 20 most frequent 6-gram patterns in the corpus. Several are rather uninteresting, e.g. containing repeated notes. The pattern in 11th place is the 6-gram 7_0_2_0_7_0, containing the root note (0) as a pedal tone. By clicking on the button "Tunes list using this pattern", we can see that this common motif occurs in The Barnacle, A Merry Christmas, and many other tunes in "The Session", a large corpus of 40,000 tunes representing the living tradition of Irish music.

dynamic_elements.textsearch_title: How many patterns do you want to see? Eg, 10.
dynamic_elements.textsearch_query:
PREFIX jams:<http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/jams/> 
SELECT ?pattern  (sum(?pattern_frequency) as ?totalFreq)
where { 
  ?observation  jams:hasFrequency ?pattern_frequency. 
  ?observation  jams:ofPattern ?pattern .} 
 group by ?pattern
 order by DESC (?totalFreq) 
LIMIT 20

chord_corpus_statistics.title: Chord Corpus Statistics
chord_corpus_statistics.subtitle: Exploring Chord data from different genres and historic periods
chord_corpus_statistics.description: Besides being one of the most studied subjects in music, harmony has attracted the interest of musicologists, computer scientists, and psychologists due to its multi-faceted and inter-disciplinary nature. The basic constituents of harmony are chords, groups of simultaneous notes, and their progressions, which convey notions of consonance (pleasant, euphonious) or dissonance (unpleasant, discordant) in music. The Chord Corpus (ChoCo) is a large-scale dataset that semantically integrates harmonic data from 18 different sources in various representations and formats (Harte, Leadsheet, Roman numerals, ABC). We leverage JAMS (JSON Annotated Music Specification), a popular data structure for annotations in Music Information Retrieval, to effectively represent a variety of chord-related information (chord, key, mode, etc.) in a uniform way. On top of it, we propose a novel ontology modelling music annotations and involved entities (artists, scores, etc.), build a 30M triple knowledge graph on chords, and find 3K links to other datasets (MIDI-LD, LED).

dynamic_elements.count_query:
PREFIX jams: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/jams/>
PREFIX mf: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/musical-features/>
PREFIX core: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/core/>
PREFIX prov: <http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#>
PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#>
PREFIX xsd: <http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#>
SELECT (COUNT(DISTINCT ?s) AS ?count) WHERE {?s rdf:type core:Composer}

PREFIX jams: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/jams/>
PREFIX mf: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/musical-features/>
PREFIX core: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/core/>
PREFIX prov: <http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#>
PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#>
PREFIX xsd: <http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#>
SELECT (COUNT(DISTINCT ?s) AS ?count) WHERE {?s rdf:type core:Performer}

PREFIX jams: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/jams/>
PREFIX mf: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/musical-features/>
PREFIX core: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/core/>
PREFIX prov: <http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#>
PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#>
PREFIX xsd: <http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#>
SELECT (COUNT(DISTINCT ?s) AS ?count) WHERE {?s rdf:type jams:JAMSAnnotation}

PREFIX jams: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/jams/>
PREFIX mf: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/musical-features/>
PREFIX core: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/core/>
PREFIX prov: <http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#>
PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#>
PREFIX xsd: <http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#>
SELECT (COUNT(DISTINCT ?s) AS ?count) WHERE {?s rdf:type jams:JAMSScoreAnnotation}

PREFIX jams: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/jams/>
PREFIX mf: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/musical-features/>
PREFIX core: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/core/>
PREFIX prov: <http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#>
PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#>
PREFIX xsd: <http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#>
SELECT (COUNT(DISTINCT ?s) AS ?count) WHERE {?s rdf:type jams:JAMSAudioAnnotation}

dynamic_elements.chart_query:
PREFIX jams: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/jams/>
PREFIX mf: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/musical-features/>
PREFIX core: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/core/>
PREFIX prov: <http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#>
PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#>
PREFIX xsd: <http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#>
SELECT distinct ?label (count(distinct ?s) as ?count) 
WHERE {?s rdf:type jams:JAMSAnnotation;
	jams:hasAnnotationType ?label}  
GROUP BY ?label  
ORDER BY DESC(?count) LIMIT 10

dynamic_elements.count_query:
PREFIX jams: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/jams/>
PREFIX mf: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/musical-features/>
PREFIX core: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/core/>
PREFIX prov: <http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#>
PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#>
PREFIX xsd: <http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#>
SELECT (COUNT(DISTINCT ?s) AS ?count) WHERE {?s rdf:type jams:JAMSObservation}

dynamic_elements.text: Original Datasets

dynamic_elements.chart_query:
PREFIX jams: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/jams/>
PREFIX mf: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/musical-features/>
PREFIX core: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/core/>
PREFIX prov: <http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#>
PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#>
PREFIX xsd: <http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#>
SELECT distinct ?label (count(distinct ?s) as ?count) 
WHERE {?s ?p ?o ; 
    prov:wasDerivedFrom ?label .}  
GROUP BY ?label  
ORDER BY DESC(?count) LIMIT 9

dynamic_elements.text: Annotator Types

dynamic_elements.chart_query:
PREFIX jams: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/jams/>
PREFIX mf: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/musical-features/>
PREFIX core: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/core/>
PREFIX prov: <http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#>
PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#>
PREFIX xsd: <http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#>
SELECT distinct ?label (count(distinct ?s) as ?count) 
WHERE {?s ?p ?o ; 
    jams:hasAnnotatorType ?raw_label .
  BIND (REPLACE(STR(?raw_label), "^.*/([^/]*)$", "$1") as ?label)
}  
GROUP BY ?label  
ORDER BY DESC(?count) LIMIT 9

PREFIX jams: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/jams/>
PREFIX mf: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/musical-features/>
PREFIX core: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/core/>
PREFIX prov: <http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#>
PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#>
PREFIX xsd: <http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#>
PREFIX ja: <http://jena.hpl.hp.com/2005/11/Assembler#>
SELECT distinct ?label (count(distinct ?s) as ?count) 
WHERE {?s rdf:type jams:JAMSAnnotation;
    jams:includesObservation ?observation.
  ?observation rdfs:label ?label .
}  
GROUP BY ?label  
ORDER BY DESC(?count) 
LIMIT 10

dynamic_elements.text: Chord Data

dynamic_elements.chart_query:
PREFIX jams: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/jams/>
PREFIX mf: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/musical-features/>
PREFIX core: <http://w3id.org/polifonia/ontology/core/>
PREFIX prov: <http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#>
PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#>
PREFIX xsd: <http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#>
PREFIX ja: <http://jena.hpl.hp.com/2005/11/Assembler#>
SELECT distinct ?label (count(distinct ?s) as ?count) 
WHERE {?s rdf:type jams:JAMSAnnotation;
    jams:hasAnnotationType "chord_roman" ;
    jams:includesObservation ?observation .
  ?observation rdfs:label ?label .
}  
GROUP BY ?label  
ORDER BY DESC(?count) 
LIMIT 10

tunes_statistics.title: Tunes Statistics
tunes_statistics.description: The project is about relations between songs from different geographical origins.

dynamic_elements.text: This data story presents relations between four collections of European Folk Songs: The Meertens Tune Collections (MTC) (Dutch), The Essen Folksong Collection (German), The Session corpus (Irish), and the Ceol Rince na hÉireann corpus (Irish).
The total number of songs in the four collections is:
Distributed over the collections as follows:

dynamic_elements.chart_title: Count of songs in the four collections

dynamic_elements.text: The Meertens corpus (Dutch) contains Tune Family annotations. All songs that can be considered the 'same' song are grouped in a Tune Family. The total number of tune families:
For the Dutch data set, we also have metadata about the sources of the songs, including printed books, manuscripts, audio recordings, leaflets, etc. The number of sources for the Dutch songs is:

dynamic_elements.chart_title: Distribution of Dutch sources over time

dynamic_elements.text: We are interested in relations between the songs from different geographic origins. Therefore, we compute the similarity between all pairs of songs. Songs with high similarity across collections are specifically of interest.

dynamic_elements.chart_title: Count of highly similar song pairs across collections
dynamic_elements.chart_query:
PREFIX : <http://example.com/tunes/>
SELECT ?label (COUNT(?song) AS ?count)
WHERE {
  ?song :highlysimilar ?othersong .
  ?song :songcollection ?labela .
  ?othersong :songcollection ?labelb .
  BIND(concat(str(?labela), "-", str(?labelb) ) as ?label)
 } GROUP BY ?label
dynamic_elements.chart_series: N. of similar songs per collection

dynamic_elements.text: This shows that the Dutch and German collections are stronger connected than the Dutch and the Irish, while, not surprisingly, the two Irish collections have a large number of songs in common.

dynamic_elements.textsearch_query:
PREFIX tune: <http://example.com/tunes/>
PREFIX bds: <http://www.bigdata.com/rdf/search#>
PREFIX dct: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/>
PREFIX rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#>
SELECT DISTINCT ?song ?songLabel ?tunefamily 
WHERE {
?songtitle bds:search <<searchterm>> .
?song dct:title ?songLabel .  
?song a tune:Song .    
?song tune:songtunefamily ?tfid .   
?tfobj rdf:label ?tfid .   
 ?tfobj tune:tunefamilyname ?tunefamily .}
LIMIT 40

PREFIX : <http://example.com/tunes/>
PREFIX bds: <http://www.bigdata.com/rdf/search#>
PREFIX dct: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/>
PREFIX rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#>
SELECT DISTINCT ?tunefamily ?tunefamilyLabel WHERE {
?tunefamilyLabel bds:search <<searchterm>> .
?tunefamily rdf:label ?tfid . 
?tunefamily :tunefamilyname ?tunefamilyLabel .}
LIMIT 20

dynamic_elements.action_query:
PREFIX : <http://example.com/tunes/>
PREFIX dct: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/>
PREFIX rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#>
SELECT DISTINCT ?song ?songLabel  
WHERE {
<<item>> rdf:label ?tunefamily .
?song :songtunefamily ?tunefamily .
?song dct:title ?songLabel . }

tonalities.title: Tonalities
tonalities.curator:
Thomas Bottini
Adam Filaber
Christophe Guillotel-Nothmann
Marco Gurrieri
tonalities.description: This story (under construction) presents some key information about Tonalities and its annotation interface. It also shows how the pilot study evolves and how stakeholders use it for their purposes.
